history.subject: Renewed commitment to academic integrity and equitable instruction
history.content:
The Faculty Senate and the Student Assembly endorsed the following renewed commitment to academic integrity and equitable instructions:

HonorFinal.pdf

All students and TAs must review it (and the modifications to the Syllabus discussed in @594) at this time and contact me directly (via Piazza private, via email or via OH) if they have any concerns.  

Thanks!

history.subject: HotCRP Submissions
history.content:
Please remember that we will be updating the same HotCRP submission for each milestone. Please do not create new submissions. Instead, we will be editing the original submission each time. Several of you will have received an email about one of your submissions being deleted (if you were attached to multiple submissions); this will make sure that you are only attached to one submission.

history.subject: Ready to re-start
history.content:
I am looking forward to re-start the 4300 lectures on Tuesday, April 7.   
>
In thinking about how to organize the rest of the semester, in addition to preserving the 4300 learning objectives, our goal was to achieve a good tradeoff between the hands-on interactive experience (the "4300 experience) and being sensitive to the hardship this situation imposes on students (e.g., an important source of stress, limited connectivity, time zone differences, etc.).  I have discussed different options at length with the course staff and with other faculty, and have considered the feedback I got from students (through surveys, piazza and OH) and here is the path that I believe strikes the best balance:
>
A) Lectures will be offered live at our regular times.   Please plan to attend the live lectures, if your current situation allows it.   The next few lectures will focus on supervised and unsupervised techniques for text mining (topics that are very relevant to your project).
>
B) Recordings will be made available shortly after the lecture.  We ask everybody that is unable to attend the live lecture to watch the recording lectures in the 12 hours following their postings (please email me if this does not work for you).  This way all students (regardless of timezone) will be in sync with the course material, we can have meaningful discussions on Piazza and in OH,  and teams can jointly work on integrating the respective content and methodologies into their projects.   
>
We will also experiment with the Live Q&A on Piazza, so students that can not attend the live class can still ask/answer questions and communicate with students that attended the live class on the class topics.
>
C) While you are encouraged to attend/watch lectures, attendance of regular lectures will no longer be mandatory. 
>
D) We are drastically relaxing our expectations for participation.  In particular, we expect the level of participation to be as if the semester ended with the Midterm.  This means that if you completely stop participating at that point, your partial participation grade (Feb 20 Partial Participation grade on CMS) automatically becomes your final grade (i.e., your grade can no longer decrease).  At this point, you can only increase your participation grade and there will be plenty of opportunities to participate on Piazza (e.g., providing feedback to app prototypes).  But there are more things in life beyond grades, so I expect you to keep participating both in class and on Piazza regardless, and help keep lectures engaging.
>
E) Future in-class quizzes will be optional.  While you are encouraged to complete them, they will not count towards your grade.
>
F) Your main workload for the remaining of the semester will come from your team project @583.  We have made several adjustments to help you with completing your project remotely.
>
G) We will continue to offer virtual OH @573 and hope to see you there. You are also expected to meet remotely with your team-TA according to the roadmap highlighted in @583.  
>
We are dealing with an unprecedented situation, so I am sure there will some unexpected challenges along the way.  In the spirit of "relevance feedback" we might have to adapt the current plan as we learn more.  Together, the 4300 staff and you the students, are sharing the goal of having the best 4300 experience possible in this odd circumstance.  So I am sure we'll make it work.
>
Prof. DNM
#pin

children.subject: For "your partial participation grade automatically becomes your final grade", is the partial participation grade the CMS assignment listed as "Participation until Feb20th (partial grade)"?
yes, that's the one (if you participated since then, we'll make sure to count that as well of course).
Will the grading percentages be changed?
While that is not currently the plan, I am not discarding that possibility.  Keep in mind however that S/U is now an option.

Now it is possible that some students take S/U whereas others take letter grade within the same group, so they might have different expectations of the course workload. How can we balance this? Thanks a lot!

This is a great question, I was going to touch on this in the first lecture but let me preface it here. 

First, I am optimistic that students will be collegial and will be driven by a common desire to put out a great app they can be proud of, share on their CV, etc.  For example, I know many past students that feature their apps on their CV or in their statements.  As mentioned above, there are more things in life than grades.  

Second, all groups are required (as per P02) to maintain a shared spreadsheet with each team member's efforts.   We will take this into account when grading. 

Third, I am encouraging each group to have a frank discussion about each team member's plans and limitations (e.g., technical limitations, family commitments, etc.).   The remote teamwork survey (@577) was supposed to get this discussion started.  So far the results of the survey are encouraging, and I am hoping team-members will be accommodating to each other's limitations.  However, for the students that feel they can no longer work with their current teams, we will allow regroupings until the P02 deadline next Friday.  They need to reach out to your current team's TA and to the grad TAs to ask to be re-grouped and we'll do our best to help them find another team.

history.subject: Flask/Heroku setup debugging thread
history.content:
March 6 and March 7 we will have dedicated troubleshooting OH to help any team that encounters any issues when following the Flask/Heroku instructions for P01 (@545).

In the meanwhile, you have two options if you need help:

A) use follow-ups on this note if you have specific questions about the setup.  We are low on TA-power until April 6 (due to the break), so I'll encourage peer-support until then.  If nothing else, this will be a repository of known issues/solutions to run through in the troubleshooting OHs mentioned above.

B) Attend the grad TAs OHs (@573).

#pin

Hello! I run into error when I installed the psycopg2-2.7.7, then I followed the instruction in the error section and changed psycopg2-2.7.7 to psycopg2-binary, which installed psycopg2 successfully. But now I have another issue when running python3 app.py, which shows the following bugs....

Exception in thread Thread-1:

....

...

/venv/lib/python3.8/site-packages/gevent/_tblib.py", line 202, in as_traceback

    code = CodeType(

TypeError: an integer is required (got type bytes)

Many thanks!
seems to be a Python 3.8 versioning issue: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58700384/how-to-fix-typeerror-an-integer-is-required-got-type-bytes-error-when-tryin
Oh, that's right. It now works! Thank you so much!!

history.subject: Project Milestone 2 (P02): Project Update: Data, examples and updated description
history.content:
Due Friday, 4/10/2020 at 11:59pm

 

Deliverables:

CMS

  • The PDF including the 4 points  described below

  • The sample dataset (a file smaller than 10MB)

HotCRP (https://cornell-4300-2020sp.hotcrp.com)

  • Edit your project submission (DO NOT create a new submission)

  • For the project abstract, update any points in the description that have changed since P01

  • For the project submission, upload the PDF described above (the same as posted to CMS); this will replace your P01 submission

Real life (over Zoom):

  • Meet with your team's TA (you will be contacted by your assigned TA to schedule a meeting)

 

Instructions:

 

You need to turn in an updated description of your project and a sample of your data. Specifically, your update should have the following sections:

 

  1. Some statistics and basic exploration of (a portion of) your dataset. Your goal should be to bring your reader from knowing nothing about your dataset to having a good feel for it and how you're going to use it.  This should be 2-3 paragraphs long, and include at least 2 plots and a few examples. At this point you need to demonstrate that the dataset you are proposing is feasible to use: this means you only need a sample  of the final data, but that sample has to be of non-trivial size and should reflect properties of the final data.

 

Discuss:

  • How many examples are in the current sample of your data?  How many do you plan to have for your final project? (it is OK for these numbers to be the same if you already have the final dataset)

  • Identify relevant statistics: what are the distributions of those statistics? (histograms are fine)

  • Now that you have looked closer at the data source, do you anticipate any challenges from a data perspective and why? (e.g. is your dataset too large to fit in memory? Would it take too long to collect all the data you need?)

  • if you are using a supervised ML approach,  you must highlight what the training labels for your ML component will be, how you will get them, and how you will use them. Clarification 04/06: if you are not yet sure what you will be doing for the ML component, that's perfectly fine (make a note of that in the proposal, you will not lose points for this); you will have the opportunity to clarify the ML component in a later milestone after we cover more material in class. This point is only relevant for teams that have included a supervised ML approach into their description (i.e., teams for which a supervised approach is a core part to their proposed app).  

  • If you plan to collect additional data, write a clear plan for data collection, including the expected size of the data and discussing the collection timeframe taking into account API limitations/rules

 

       Additionally, you will be required to submit a zip file containing a sample of your dataset on CMS.  This dataset can be raw (e.g., raw html files).  If your dataset is larger than 10MB, turn in a 10MB subset of your dataset instead.

 

  1. Some "sketched" examples and descriptions of idealized final inputs and outputs. This should give the reader a good idea of what your system will actually do. This should be 1-2 paragraphs, include 2 distinct examples from your data sample, and should include a high-level description of the types of engineering challenges you'll need to solve to make this example a reality (to get from the input to the output)

    For a (very silly) example of the types of things we are looking for: if I was making a movie recommendation system that recommended movies based on the types of food in them, I might include something like this in my writeup:

                 ~ User input : hamburger

                 ~ System output : hamburger - "A hamburger (or cheeseburger when served with a slice of cheese) is a sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun." This is a valid food query. Goodburger (10 occurrences), Ratatouille (7 occurrences), Spinning Plates (3 occurrences) [.032 seconds]

                 ~ Given the query "hamburger," the system queries the database of food items we will precompute to ensure that the user has input a valid query. Because this database is potentially too large to search linearly, we will need to use binary search or a hash table to store everything. Once we determine that it is a valid query, we will print the description for the food item. Next, we will use our food finding algorithm…

 

 

  1. An updated description Start from the P01 abstract.  If your exploration of the data or discussion with your team’s TA changed your plan make the respective changes to the abstract.  Use color-coding to distinguish the changes in your text from P01 and briefly explain what lead you to these changes.  

      In addition to what was there in the P01 abstract, you should discuss:

  • How does your approach compare with existing systems?  (What are the closest existing system to your proposed app?  What unique capabilities will app will over these?)

 

  1. A weekly schedule including the concrete steps that will lead to your in-class demo and to the final report (e.g., data collection, data analysis, implementation of methods, testing, etc.). This should include a tentative division of work between team members (also indicate special-powers: e.g., X has front-end experience, Y has experience with ML; this will help us understand whether what you are proposing is realistic). Keep in mind key dates from our roadmap:

  • April 20: First live prototype, a brief presentation and demo in class with a few live examples

  • May 4: Final app goes live

        

Starting now you should also keep a shared spreadsheet, where each team member should indicate for each week, details about the work they’ve done for the project and the time it took them.  Share this spreadsheet with your team’s TA, but we will ask you in your final report for this division of labor between teammates. This spreadsheet should also help you make sure nobody is freeloading.  (If you have any concerns that some teammates are not putting enough work into the project, please let the course staff know as soon as possible; it is unlikely we’ll be able to do much about it in May).

 

Successful write-ups tend to be roughly 2-3 pages long (excluding references)

children.subject:
For the question How many examples are in the current sample of your data?, I'm a bit confused as to what examples means in this context. Is it, how many examples of queries can be made with the sample we're providing?

Thanks!

Think of example as "documents",i.e., potential answers to your query.  What a "document" depends on your applications.  if you were searching for characters in a TV show, then you would have as many examples as characters in that TV show.

history.subject: Updated Project Roadmap + video tutorial for P01
history.content:
As we are gearing up for the re-start of the semester, we are now ready to share with you the updated project roadmap.  As discussed, there will be no additional assignments or exams in 4300, so this roadmap should give you a rather complete picture of your workload in the course for the rest of the semester.

As before, we are breaking the project into multiple sub-tasks to ensure we can give you feedback and guide you in a timely manner.  While at a glance, this might seem a bit overwhelming, conceptually there are three coarse parts of the project roadmap, loosely indicated with colors: (GREEN) Pinning down a feasible project proposal (this is simply finishing up what we started before the semester was suspended);  (BLUE) Developing an initial prototype; and (PURPLE) Iterative refinement towards the final app.

Here is the roadmap: Project_Milestone_Map__CS_INFO_4300__Spring_2020_for_distribution_replan.pdf

A couple of other important points:

1. To help you get started with the first step P01 (@545) we've put together a video tutorial of the Flask/Heroku setup (to complement the instructions already present on the git repository): https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU2RF0LMCVxVtcvK0VQXBurn75x6WU3sI

2. Soon we will also assign TAs to each team (the TAs will contact you on your respective Piazza project).  Please make sure to complete the remote team-work survey to help us in the process @577 (thank you if you have completed it already).

Prof. DNM

PS: I realize this is a challenging period for many of you.  Recognizing that there are no general solutions, I want to reiterate our invitation for joining OH (both mine and those of the graduate TAs @573) to discuss any difficulties that are currently encountering or are foreseeing.  Our goal is to do our part in helping you have the best possible end-of-semester given the circumstances.

history.subject: Remote team-work survey
history.content:
In order to better facilitate remote teamwork for the 4300 projects we would need your help.  Please review the survey below, discuss with your team-mates and designate ONE team member to fill out the survey with your team's responses.  The sooner you can do this the easier it will be for us to plan. 

We are aware that everybody's plans are in flux, so these answers are non-committal. This survey is just meant to give the course staff some preliminary information and to identify some potential issues early on.  This survey should also help your team plan for remote teamwork after the break.

And here is the link to the survey: https://forms.gle/3W7NiZgRbDhuj91i9

Thanks!

ps: I wish I could promise this will be the last survey...

children.subject: What is the HotCRP submission number asked for in the survey?

When you made a submission on HotCRP for P01pre you got assigned a submission number.  You should be able to see that if you sign into hotcrp and look at your submission.  If you can't find it, it's OK if you say in that field that you don't know it.
<md>It would be the number next to the # symbol on our submission link on HotCRP, right?</md>
yes

history.subject: Virtual Grad TA Office Hours
history.content:
I hope you have all been keeping well and managing as best as you can under the circumstances. We wanted to provide an update on Office Hours during the break. Andrew, Trevor and I will be holding office hours during the break in a virtual format. These are primarily there so you have someone to speak with if you would like to discuss exam solutions or have anything else you need to talk through that relates to the course.

Our office hours remain unchanged and are up to date on the class calendar. We will be using Discord to manage these office hours. history.subject: Class suspended until April 6 - no lectures, no due dates
history.content:
Following the President's announcement, we will be suspending the class until April 6. 

This means no lectures and no project milestones (or assignments) due until then.  The tutorial this Sunday is canceled and we do not expect the undergraduate TAs to be able to help with anything in the next 3 weeks.  We will post an updated project roadmap in the following weeks, as we find out more information.  We will, of course, have to adjust both the schedule and our expectations. 

Right now you (and our TAs) should not worry about this class and instead focus on how to best cope with the current situation and plan for your return home.

Assuming no further changes in university policy, we will resume the class (with virtual lectures) on April 6.   

PS: As always, I am happy to receive any of your thoughts and suggestions.

history.subject: Project Milestone 1 (P01): Proposal abstract
history.content:
Due Monday, 3/16/2020 at 11:59pm

[Edits: updated due date @583, added link to video walkthrough]

Due Wednesday, 4/8/2020 at 11:59pm 

Prerequisites:

  • (P01 pre-check) Form groups of 4-5 students. You can use Piazza to search for team­mates (@6).

  • (P01 pre-check) You should have a placeholder submission in HotCRP  (with all of your team members as authors) and a group formed on CMS.

  • (P01 pre-check) You should have a Piazza note in 'project_brainstorming' with your group's project idea

 

The purpose of this first milestone is to get you thinking more concretely about the final project and to complete the technical setup.  Components of this milestone are:

 

  1. As a group, set up the project framework using the provided Flask Template for Python 3. We will not limit you to using this project template if you would rather use a different framework or language; however, the Flask template  is the only template for which the course staff will support.

    The Flask template can be found at:
    https://github.com/CornellNLP/CS4300_Flask_template


    Our amazing TAs put together this video walkthrough for you: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLU2RF0LMCVxVtcvK0VQXBurn75x6WU3sI (keep the link private)


    At this point you need to fork the project and modify the index.html to include your team members’ names and netids to personalize the template. (Don't forget to add all your team­ members to the GitHub project.) You also need to deploy the app to a unique heroku domain that is publicly available (as explained in the README of the flask template). Make your forks public. (You may also use your personal GitHub account.)


    The optional Project Setup tutorial session (@481) this Sunday will guide you through this. 

    We also provide access to a Django template in Python 3  that was used in previous iterations of this course, if you would like. However, it will not be officially supported by course staff. CS4300 Django template

  2. Produce a write-up of a (roughly) one page project proposal abstract that expands and refines the ideas discussed on Piazza. Explain the goal of your proposed application, and describe your application in terms of input, output, and discuss use cases. List possible data sources, and clearly discuss the role of the information retrieval component and of the social component. Optionally (considering that we haven’t yet covered this topic in class), discuss the third component: machine learning. Use the bolded terms in this paragraph to organize your proposal.


    We expect that the details of the project are likely to change as the semester continues, but we want to see a general direction that will form the basis of your future discussions.

 

Create a PDF containing:

  • The names and netids of each team member

  • A link to the PM1 brainstorming Piazza note 

  • A link to your GitHub repository and to the URL of the Heroku app at the top of the documents 

  • The proposal abstract 

 

Submissions will be as follows:

CMS

  • The PDF as described above

 

HotCRP

  • Edit the submission created for the P01 pre-check (do not create a new submission)

  • For the project abstract, add a link to the Heroku app URL. From the PM01 Pre-check (@401), the abstract should already contain the list of members in your team, one per line, and a link to your Piazza post in'project_brainstorming' 

  • For the project submission, upload the PDF described above (the same as posted to CMS)

  • Second reminder, please mark any conflicts of interest with other students and/or TAs on the HotCRP submission, this will be your last chance to do so before we assign peer reviewers.

history.subject: P01 Setup - Special OH this Monday and Tuesday
history.content:
If after going through the tutorial and the video walkthrough (@545 @583) you are still encountering any issues with setting up your the Flask/Heroku template, make sure to go to our special virtual Project Setup OH (see course calendar or attachment below). First one is on Monday morning 11am ET, and we have a mix of Mac/Windows/Linux OH.  For setup help only go to the OHs that have "setup" in the title.   (If it turns out that you are having issues with the setup, but nobody in your team can make it to any of the OH, please contact us via a private Note.)

Our TAs have very graciously offered to hold these extra OH to make sure you are ready to go.  It is unlikely that we'll be able to help you with the setup on Wednesday (when P01 is due) since for this stage debugging is very machine-specific.

For setup OHs, after joining the waiting room in discord (@573, https://discord.gg/BrARECW), go directly to the active voice channel where the TAs will be waiting.

history.subject: Database Integration
history.content:
In the Flask tutorial, we are asked to created my_app_db and then integrate Postgres into a Flask app., but I am a little bit  confused about how to achieve this. 

like:

Should we build a db by ourselves? 

How can I connect postgresql and how can I use contents or results from the database?

Is there any instructions to tell us how to use the database?

thanks!

please use @588

cc: note that as stated in the video tutorial, it is up to you to how to set up your database. You may use a static database (e.g. a large JSON file) or a proper database like Postgres (and others). The tutorial writeup already provides detailed instructions on how to connect Postgres to Flask (search for 'Database setup') so please look there.
please use @588

history.subject: problem with rocchio
history.content: I am trying to use rocchio but I am not sure if this is an issue I have to worry about. say the user has queried "corn field" and the top document is about "pop corn". they mark this document as irrelevant, which then lowers the weight of "pop" and "corn". but we still cared about "corn" and it was the "pop" value that was too high in our vector. as a result, it is now harder to find documents about "corn field". is this a problem that can come up, and is there a way to use rocchio so this does not happen?

Theoretically this could happen, if you only have 1 bit of feedback. Ideally, you’d want to have a few relevant documents (which are much harder to find) and run multiple tests with different weights in the Rocchio update rule to find a better linear combination by whatever metric(s) you are using. Usually negative feedback will have a low weight because there are many more irrelevant document than relevant ones.

You may also modify the algorithm in some other way however this may have adverse effects.

history.subject: New Project Idea

You could consider existing datasets in the academic domain like arXiv (https://arxiv.org/help/bulk_data) if it fits your project focus.

history.subject: Midterm Grades
history.content:
Grades for the midterm will be released shortly via Gradescope (we are going through some final checks).  We have already discussed the solutions on Thursday in class (that seems so long ago!)

 

Since this is not graded on a curve, I wanted to give you a few details on how to interpret the grades.   

 

The basics:  As stated in the Syllabus, the midterm counts towards 20% of the final grade for this class (20 out of 100 final grade points).   The maximum possible score on the midterm is 60 points.  This means that 6 points on the midterm roughly correspond to 2 final grade points.

 

How to interpret the grade:

 

If your score is over 50 (you lost less than 3.5 points of the final grade) in the midterm I consider you have an excellent understanding of all the key concepts of the class.  If you lost some points, that is likely due to exam-induced stress.   Over half of the class falls into this category, which is reassuring.

 

if your score is roughly between 40 and 50 (you lost less than 7 points of the final grade)  you have good control of the concepts, but there are likely some small holes that might have lead you to spend too much time on some problems.

 

if your score is between 30 and 40 you likely have some important gaps in your understanding of the class concepts. Consider going to (virtual) OH with our TAs and/or signing up for an OH with Prof. DNM: https://dnm-office-hours.youcanbook.me

 

if your score is below 30 you have some major gaps in your understanding of the class concepts.  You are strongly encouraged to sign up for and OH with Prof. DNM : https://dnm-office-hours.youcanbook.me

 

 

Overall the class did a great job, and we are extremely proud of your hard work, especially considering the adverse situation.  Thank you again for helping run a smooth midterm and for helping each other on Piazza!

 

If you think you did not do as well as you wished, you have several opportunities to recover the final points via Extra Credit.   This extra credit system (and the relatively low weight of the midterm on the final grade) was designed specifically to recognize that not everybody is equally good at dealing with the stress conditions of an exam. 
We also recognize that the atmosphere surrounding the midterm was not ideal for focusing on learning, many of us had much more important things to worry about.  In accordance with the university guidelines, we will allow for students to switch to an S/U for this semester.  This is something that will be handled centrally by the University.  
Regrade requests
If requested, we will regrade the entire exam, so it is possible that you will also lose points.  When regarding we will not award extra partial credit for incorrect solutions as this would be unfair to other students who were graded to the same standards (and the discussion about what deserves partial credit and how much is quite subjective).  For the same reasons, we will not alter the grading rubric.  So if you know that your answer to the question you are contesting was not correct, there is no point in asking for a regrade.  You have until Thursday, April 9, 10am to review your graded exam and make a regrade request by emailing Prof DNM and all 4 grad TAs (emails listed on the course website).
We expect to be slow in handling regrade requests, since given the recent developments we don't want to require any work from the undergraduate TAs until April 6.
Academic misconduct reminder
A quick reminder that, as stated on the exam, "storing, sharing or distributing any images or reproductions of the contents of this exam constitutes academic misconduct".  This applies to the graded exam that you will access via Gradescope, so make sure not to store on your device the images of your exam or share any reproductions of its contents.

history.subject: F1 Equation
history.content: Can someone explain what the F1 equation does/says?

@397



F1 is the f-score where $$\beta = 1$$ where $$\beta = \frac{1-\alpha}{\alpha}$$. In this choice of $$\beta$$, the equation weights precision and recall of equal importance when evaluating the results of the IR system.


The F1 score is a measure of weighted harmonic mean of precision and recall. It’s a way to tell a balance of precision and recall. When the F1 score reaches the best value(=1), it means perfect precision and recall. When it is 0, it means lowest precision and lowest recall.

@397

F1 is the f-score where $$\beta = 1$$ where $$\beta = \frac{1-\alpha}{\alpha}$$. In this choice of $$\beta$$, the equation weights precision and recall of equal importance when evaluating the results of the IR system.

history.subject: Can someone explain merge postings for more than two terms or with the word NOT?
history.content: the above

You initialize a list and the pointers like you would with AND. If the pointers are pointing at two different numbers, add the smaller one to the list and increment that one. If the pointers are pointing at the same number then increment both of them.

If the shorter list's last index's value is smaller than the other's pointer's value, add the entire end of the longer list. Otherwise keep iterating and incrementing the other pointer.

history.subject: Can someone explain normalization to me?
history.content: I think I vaguely understand how it is trying to account for the difference in document lengths, but how does the denominator in our cosine similarity equation achieve that?

Vector normalization is when you want the vector to have a norm of length 1. You can also think of the cosine similarity equation as having two normalized vector multiplied with each other. To normalize a vector, you divide by its magnitude.


By normalizing and making the length of every vector one, you're essentially making size of each vector the same, accounting for size difference, while also keeping the values relative to each other the same.

Vector normalization is when you want the vector to have a norm of length 1. You can also think of the cosine similarity equation as having two normalized vector multiplied with each other. To normalize a vector, you divide by its magnitude.
Make sure you also understand the geometric intuition: the angle does not "know" the length of the vectors that define it.

history.subject: Boolean search - binary weights
history.content: Do boolean searches always have binary weights?
No, they can have non-binary weights (for example, if we used the tf-idf as weights)

I am not sure what you mean by a "search" having a weight.   Generally, for boolean search you would use a binary representation (you want to know if a term is or is not in a document), and normally you would use an inverted index to run a binary search (rather than a vector representation).

children.subject: How would one use boolean search with TF-IDF weights? In example with posting-merge algorithm, we are just looking for Doc IDs that include the query word (or words) and not the excluded "not" word (or words), how does this extend when words have weights with them?

Boolean search doesn't use a term-document matrix. A boolean search uses the inverted index representation of documents. For both of the terms in a boolean search, you compare the values in the postings lists (aka the list of the documents containing the terms). I believe we did this in quiz 2 from class.
Thank you, my brain broke when I wrote the question but this gives me the correct answer.

history.content: In the vector space model, it says that the vectors are of length N - number of unique terms and that this is independent of number of types. If types is the set of tokens - how these two different?
Types is the number of distinct words while tokens are the total number of words

children.subject: Yes i understand that but N is unique terms so how is that different from types which is the set of total words.

It's not. N is number of unique terms, aka number of types. I'm guessing you're referring to the sentence "Note that the all document vectors have the same length, N (i.e., the number of terms), independent of how many of these types it contains," in which case it's just saying whether a document only contains one of one type or several of several types, its vector will always be of length N.

history.subject: second question, sample questions
history.content:
Confused about the concept of a centroid and how that relates to the Rocchio equation in question 2 of the practice questions we were given. 

Thanks!

The centroid in the context of Rocchio is basically an n-dimensional "center" of various tf-idf vectors (of the all the relevant and irrelevant docs), where n is the number of relevant terms. For instance, if all that existed was the word "hello", then documents d1, d2 might have vectors <0>, <2> and the "center" of all those 1-dimensional vectors would be simply the mean, <1>. This centroid is an average representation of the frequency of all relevant terms present in the document, and this is scalable to cases where there are 2, 3, 4, ...  dimensions (terms of interest), except you are now taking the mean per index of the terms. 

In Rocchio, you have coefficients that can push you closer to the centroid of all relevant documents while staying away from the influence of irrelevant documents. This may be helpful because you want the user to provide feedback regarding relevancy such that the query can be updated to land closer to the centroid of relevant documents and thus result in better rankings the next time around. Moreover, the reason why you may get better results and rankings with your updated Rocchio query is that because it's (hopefully) closer to the centroid of relevant documents, and the query will thus be closer to the actual relevant documents, resulting in higher similarity measures with relevant documents and thus better results.

Moreover, the reason why you may get better results and rankings with your updated Rocchio query is that because it's (hopefully) closer to the centroid of relevant documents, the query will thus be closer to the actual relevant documents, resulting in higher similarity measures and thus better results.

The centroid in the context of Rocchio is basically an n-dimensional "center" of various tf-idf vectors (of the all the relevant and irrelevant docs), where n is the number of relevant terms. For instance, if all that existed was the word "hello", then documents d1, d2 might have vectors <0>, <2> and the "center" of all those 1-dimensional vectors would be simply the mean, <1>. This centroid is an average representation of the frequency of all relevant terms present in the document, and this is scalable to cases where there are 2, 3, 4, ...  dimensions (terms of interest), except you are now taking the mean per index of the terms. 

In Rocchio, you have coefficients that can push you closer to the centroid of all relevant documents while staying away from the influence of irrelevant documents. This may be helpful because you want the user to provide feedback regarding relevancy such that the query can be updated to land closer to the centroid of relevant documents and thus result in better rankings the next time around.

history.subject: Positive Feedback
history.content: Why is positive feedback more valuable than negative feedback (i.e. in rocchio)

Since typically, the relevant documents should have more impact on the query, so often, beta > gamma.

Also, usually negative values get converted to 0 anyways so, in a way, there's a bound to how much you can subtract. On the other hand, we don't limit how much a term weight can be added. Just something I noticed, not sure if that's particularly why.

Something more relevant to this question might also be because there are much, much more irrelevant (non-relevant?) documents so saying that it's unlike an irrelevant document is much less telling/revealing than saying it's more like one of the much fewer relevant documents.
Since typically, the relevant documents should have more impact on the query, so often, beta > gamma.

history.content:
When iterating through the query for fast cosine, should we include repeats?

https://www.cs.cornell.edu/courses/cs4300/2020sp/Slides/fast_cosine_worksheet.pdf

I am assuming you mean repeats in the query like doing "olympic champion champion".

yes, because the algorithm states "for each term in q", so if there are duplicates (eg. two "champions"), you take it into account the effect twice instead of once.

history.subject: Precision @ k vs. Precision upto D (at position k)
history.content: If document D is at position k, what is the difference between Precision @ k and Precision upto D?
Precision-up-to(D) is 0 if the document D is not retrieved. Otherwise, it is the precision @ rank(D).

history.subject: Read before the midterm: Important exam taking conditions and instructions
history.content:
Please read this carefully before you enter the lecture hall, as you will need to sign that you agree with these exam taking conditions.  This will also help us start on time.

 

The midterm will start on Tuesday March 10, at 2:55 in Uris G01.   Make sure to be there on time (or early, if your schedule allows for that).

 

What to bring

Your cheatsheet, two pens (non-erasable, not pencils) and your Cornell student id. A water bottle is also allowed.

What not to bring

Nothing else is needed or allowed (if you have other items with you, put them in a closed bag before you get into the lecture hall).   In particular, having any electronic devices in sight will result in your exclusion from the exam. This includes, but it is not limited to: mobile phones, smart watches, headsets, electronic pens, etc.  You need to observe this from the time you enter the lecture hall until the time you leave it. 

 

When you arrive at the lecture hall

You will need to put aside your bag next to the back wall of the lecture hall (keep only the allowed items in your hands, do not have any electronic devices on you; e.g., no phones in your pockets), and have your student ID scanned as you enter the lecture hall. Since everyone needs to scan their ID before they enter the room, we will start scanning people into the room approximately 15 minutes before the exam starts.  Apologies in advance for the line, the school only provided us with two ID scanners.

After your ID is scanned you should proceed immediately to your assigned seat. Do not enter the room or take a seat before you scan your ID.  

After you are at your designated seat put your Cornell ID next to your where your name is indicated on the cheatsheet. A TA will hand you two exam notebooks and check your cheatsheet. Do not open any of the notebooks before you are told to do so (refer to the Before the exam starts section below).

 

Where to sit

You have all received (or will receive by Tuesday morning) an individual seating assignment via CMS (the CMS assignment will also come with a seating chart, also attached here).  Starting from the blackboard, the rows are A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, J, K, L, M, N, O (A being the row closest to the blackboard and O being the row closest to the entrance; O is the row of long tables).  Letter-named rows are indicated on a piece of paper taped to the wall on both the left and right side of the classroom. Row numbering starts from the left of each row (as you face the blackboard). For example, Row A, Seat 1 is the seat closest to the left wall and blackboard.  Please make note of your seat assignment before you enter the lecture hall (and write it on your cheatsheet, see below), and after checking in with the TAs (see above) go straight to the seat assigned to you to avoid any delays. If your seat is defective or you are unable to write please raise your hand and the course staff will assist you.

 

We acknowledge that Uris G01 does not provide the best conditions for writing, but we need to work with what we have.  We took this into account in determining the time-to-content ratio for the exam.

 

Cheatsheet

As previously indicated, you are allowed to bring and use one handwritten sheet of letter or A4-sized paper (front and back).  The cheatsheet must be handwritten by you. No xerox-copies, print-outs or digital versions will be allowed. Before you come to the exam, you need to clearly write your name, netID and (importantly) the seat number that was assigned to you on the cheatsheet.   Cross out all large blocks of unwritten space on BOTH sides.

If you do not plan to prepare a cheatsheet, bring an empty page with your name, netID and the seat number that was assigned to you.  Write NO CHEATSHEET on it and cross out all the unwritten space on BOTH sides.

 

Before the exam starts

Once you are in your pre-assigned seat, you should have received two notebooks.  Do not open any of them before you are told to do so. Print your name, netid and seat (row, seat number) on the cover page of each notebook, read the instructions carefully and sign at the bottom of the cover pages.  

 

During the exam

Read the problems from the Problem Notebook and write your answers in the Answer Notebook.  You are only allowed to write in the Answers Notebook. You can use the back side of the pages in the Answer Notebook as draft space (but keep in mind that we will not grade that).  Extra pages are provided at the end of the Answer Notebook if you need to extra space for the solution of the problems.

You MUST write your netID on each page of your Answer Notebook (do this after the exam starts).  We can not grade any page that does not have your netID on it.  

 

What not to do

Any form of communication between you and another student will result in your exclusion from the exam (regardless of who initiated that communication).  If you have anything to communicate, raise your hand and wait for the course staff to come to you. If any other exam-taker is trying to communicate with you, it is your responsibility to signal that to the course staff by raising your hand.

Do not look on any other student’s answers/notes, and make sure you do not show your answers/notes to other students, as both constitute reasons for exclusion from the exam.   If any of the students sitting next to you makes you feel uncomfortable, raise your hand and wait for the course staff to come to you.

 

Remember to go to the restroom before the exam starts.

 

When you finish the exam. Case 1: after the exam time expires

Place the Answers Notebook and your cheatsheet in your Problem Notebook and wait in your seat for the course staff to come collect your exam.  Make sure to hand in all three documents (the two notebooks and your cheatsheet) to the course staff before leaving your seat. Please be patient to allow enough time for the course staff to account for your exam materials.   Under no circumstance should you leave the lecture hall with any of these (notebooks or cheatsheets), as your exam will be invalidated.

 

When you finish the exam. Case 2: before the exam time expires

Place the Answers Notebook and your cheatsheet in your Problem Notebook and raise your hand holding these three documents in your hand.  The course staff will come and collect them from you. Please be patient and avoid disturbing any of your colleagues that are still taking the exam.  After your exam is collected and accounted for, you will be told when you can leave the room (we’ll do that at certain times, to minimize the disturbance to students that are still taking the exam).

Under no circumstance should you leave the lecture hall with any of the materials (notebooks or cheatsheet), as your exam will be invalidated.

 

Good luck!

following up on @368
yes
Is the cheatsheet allowed to be on a piece of notebook paper sized 8.5 x 11 inches?

In @134 Prof. DNM said "you are allowed to have a cheatsheet: one handwritten-only, 2-sided (letter size) paper", defined as 8.5 by 11 inches (215.9 by 279.4 mm, and designated "A" by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI).

In this post, the prof said "one handwritten sheet of letter or A4-sized paper (front and back)." A4 measures 210 mm × 297 mm (8.27 in × 11.7 in) and is also size "A" by ISO 216 (international standard for paper sizes).

As area wise both are similar, either letter or A4 sized should be fine.
*both sizes should be fine. Just trim off the additional dimension (e.g. .23' off horizontally for letter) if it happens one is allowed and the other is not.

You can just use the back of the pages in the answer notebook for scratch work
No, as stated above you can only bring "two pens (non-erasable, not pencils)".

history.subject: Explaining Precision-Recall Plot
history.content: Would anyone mind explaining how to read the Precision-Recall graph and what this exactly shows about Systems 1, 2 and 3?

I personally find this graphic very helpful in explaining precision and recall.

Precision is how many of the selected items are actually relevant, and recall is how many of the relevant items have been selected.

How I understand it is: Low recall and high precision means few items have been selected, but they are all or mostly relevant. High recall and high precision means that many items have been selected and are mostly relevant. Low recall and low precision means that there are a lot of irrelevant items selected. High recall and low precision means that many relevant items have been selected, but many irrelevant items have also been selected.

I personally find this graphic very helpful in explaining precision and recall.

Precision is how many of the selected items are actually relevant, and recall is how many of the relevant items have been selected.

How I understand it is: Low recall and high precision means few items have been selected, but they are all or mostly relevant. Low recall and low precision means that few items have been selected and are mostly irrelevant. High recall and high precision means that many items have been selected and are mostly relevant. When a precision-recall curve has higher levels of precision at higher levels of recall, that means that the system prefers recall over precision (such as a system a researcher would want to use to get as many documents as possible that might be related to their topic of interest)

what is the intuition behind doing this?

history.subject: cooccurence_matrix = np.dot(term_doc_matrix.T, term_doc_matrix)
history.content: what is the intuition behind doing this?

The entry (i,j) in a cooccurence matrix should measure how often elements i and j occur together. If we think about matrix multiplication of a transposed matrix with itself (particularly a matrix of only 1s and 0s), we see that we are essentially just adding up times where both terms appear in the same document. For example, if we have term_1 appear in doc_1 and doc_3 but term_2 only appear in doc_2 and doc_3, then after the matrix multiplications, the indices (1,2) and (2,1) will just be equal to 1. So, this is a convenient way of calculating the matrix.

We can get the co occurrence matrix by doing the following:

For index (I,j) of the co occurrence matrix, take the dot product of the column i and column j of the term document matrix. This gives you the documents where both term i and j occur.
This is equivalent to taking the matrix multiplication of the transpose of the term document matrix and the term doc matrix itself. (Matrix multiplication takes the dot product of the ith row with the jth column to get element ij)

We can get the co occurrence matrix by doing the following:
For index (I,j) of the co occurrence matrix, take the dot product of the column i and column j if the term document matrix. This gives you the documents where both term i and j occur.
This is equivalent to taking the matrix multiplication of the transpose of the term document matrix and the term doc matrix itself. (Matrix multiplication takes the dot product of the ith row with the jth column to get element ij)

history.subject: Midterm Q1
history.content: I'm a bit confused on how to solve Question 1 from the Midterm practice questions?

It says in the question itself that "we keep normal penalties if target letters are introduced ahead or in between the first three letters." So we penalize more any direct changes to the first 3 letters (deletion, substitution), but there is no added penalty to insertion. Because you only care about the first three letters of the source, you only +3 if deleting, but keep insertion the same at +1. Therefore, substitution is +4 because it is +3 from deletion and +1 from insertion.

children.subject: In class, we discussed the initialization as well for D(i,0). Why would D(i,0) > 3 be i + 9?

D(i, 0) represents the cost of changing the first i characters of the source into the empty string. So, for the first 3 characters, the cost of deleting them is 3 each which is a total cost of 9. So, the cost of deleting any character after that is i + 9

Wouldn't it be i + 6? For example: D(4, 0) = D(3, 0) + 1 because deletion for characters after the first three has penalty of 1. Thus, D(4, 0) = 9 + 1 = 10. This is equal to 4 + 6 = 10 where i = 4. So I think it should be i + 6 not i + 9.
Yes, it should be D(i, 0) = i + 6 when i > 3.

history.content:
WF can be used as an alternative for TF.  Imagine you search for the query "midterm instructions" on Piazza.  The intuition is that seeing a "midterm" 1 vs 0 times in a piazza post is a big indicator that the post is relevant to your query.  Seeing it 2 vs 1 times is still a good signal, but not as important as seeing it 1 vs 0.   Seeing it 21 times vs 20 times is a very slight signal so should not affect the ranking that much (at that point you would want the ranking to be affected more by the presence or absence of the word "instructions").   WF achieves this via the logarithmic function.

The point is that there are different ways of "counting" whether a term is in a document, and we have seen a few so far: binary, TF, TF-IDF, WF.

As for the naming, I can not defend it..."word frequency" is admittedly very ambiguous.

history.subject: What is query expansion?
history.content: What methods of query expansion do we know / need to know?

Query expansions are techniques used to retrieve as many relevant results as possible while the query itself is limited. For example, a user might want to search for entries about laptops yet in the database all such machines are referred to as notebook computers. In such a scenario, we need to expand our query terms (probably including notebook computer) either through pre-compiled data or through automated ways like an automated thesaurus. The need for automated expansion naturally leads to the need to find related words which is fulfilled by the use of word embeddings. 

-------------------------------------------

More concretely, one way to expand our query would be to find similar terms. We can say terms are similar if they co-occur in the same document. In class, we covered using a co-occurrence matrix to find similar terms to our query. Each entry in the co-occurrence matrix shows the number of documents in which two terms occur together. It is computed using the term-document matrix. A further explanation of a co-occurrence matrix is in @482.

history.subject: K-Statistic and Pooling
history.content: What is the k-statistic actually measuring in relation to pooling?

The k-statistic tells us how much of the judge's agreements are based on chance. The kappa statistic is defined as (P(A) - P(E)) / (1 - P(E)), where P(A) is the proportion of times judges agreed and P(E) is proportion of times judges are expected to agree by chance. Pooling is a way of assessing relevance by getting the top k docs from different retrieval systems / annotators. 

There's a section in the MRS textbook that walks through an example of calculating the kappa statistic, which is worth taking a look at!

The k-statistic tells us how much of the judge's agreements are based on chance. The kappa statistic is defined as (P(A) - P(E)) / (1 - P(E)), where P(A) is the proportion of times judges agreed and P(E) is proportion of times judges are expected to agree by chance. Pooling is a way of assessing relevance by getting the top k docs from different retrieval systems / annotators.

children.subject: So just to clarify, the k-statistic assesses the agreements of the results of the different annotators while taking chance into account? So k = 1 means complete agreement and k = 0 means they only ever agree by chance?
Yep, that's right.
Yes. Also, k-statistic < 0 corresponds to agreement at a rate worse than random and a k-statistic > 0 corresponds to agreement at a rate better than random.
Thank you!
How do you calculate P(A) and P(E)?

P(A) = (both say yes + both say no)/total

P(E) = P(nonrelevant)^2 + P(relevant)^2
wait why is P(E) =  P(nonrelevant)^2 + P(relevant)^2?

In lecture I believe P[E] = P[annotator 1 says yes]P[annotator 2 says yes] + P[annotator 1 says no]P[annotator 2 says no]

We can multiply them because we assume they are independent. This would give us the expected agreement.

In the textbook, their calculation for P(nonrelevant) and P(relevant) don't seem to follow the "P[E] = P[annotator 1 says yes]P[annotator 2 says yes] + P[annotator 1 says no]P[annotator 2 says no]" stated above? Can someone please explain how the P(E) was calculated in this example? I don't understand why the denominators of P(nonrelevant) and P(relevant) are "400+400." Thank you!

I understand that the textbook calculates it differently but I think if you keep reading it says that there are different ways of calculating:

"P(A) is the proportion of the times the judges agreed, and P(E) is the proportion of the times they would be expected to agree by chance. There are choices in how the latter is estimated... " (pg. 165 of book or 15 in pdf).

But to answer you question, the textbook gets 400 from the total documents there are. So the probability that the document is non-relevant is defined as (the number of times judge 1 says a document is non-relevant + the number of times judge 2 says a document is non-relevant) / (total number of documents). So the expected probability is calculated that both are non-relevant or both are relevant

To clarify with P[E] from above, because they are considering the same 400 documents but possibly double counting when we add the two judges' "no"s, we need to also double count for it in the denominator. Essentially pretending there are 800 documents (double) and considering a document non-relevant if either judge considers it non-relevant
What would the answer be if we calculated P(E) the way learned in class with the example given from the textbook?
P[E] = P[annotator 1 says yes]P[annotator 2 says yes] + P[annotator 1 says no]P[annotator 2 says no] = (320/400)(310/400) + (80/400)(90/400)
I think we should follow the formula used in lecture.

What is the point of having the log function for the PMI formula? What information would we lose if we did not have the log function?

I think no information is lost if you don’t take the log, however the log splits the data into negative, positive and zero values which is convenient to analyze. Negative PMI means the co occurrences are less than at random, zero PMI means the co occurrences happen by chance, positive means co occurrences happens at a rate greater than by chance

To clarify, is the cooccurrence matrix a binary matrix (where each entry represents whether or not the terms cooccur in a document), or does it contain the number of times two terms cooccur? I know cooccurrence matrices can either have binary or term count values, but I was unsure when to use which representation.

The co-occurrence matrix is not binary. The term document matrix (A) used to make the co-occurrence matrix is binary. C = A^tA. Each entry (i, j) of the co-occurrence matrix is the number of documents that contains both terms i and j.

history.subject: Pseudo Relevance Feedback
history.content: What is pseudo relevance feedback? Does it have any relationship with Rocchio's method?

From Prof. DNM:  Relevance feedback is the general concept of using (user-provided) information about the relevance of the results returned by your system for a specific query to improve the results.   Rocchio is a specific method of how to actually improve the results (by modifying the query in a specific way).  Pseudo-relevance feedback is a (apparently sketchy) method for getting information about the relevance of the results.  You could use pseudo-relevance feedback in combination with Rocchio, as discussed in class: consider first K documents that your system would return as the set of relevant docs, then user Rocchio to update the query, then return to the user the results of this updated query.

Pseudo relevance feedback is a method by which a system performs relevance feedback by assuming the top results returned by a system are relevant. Relevance feedback means that the user gives feedback on which documents are relevant and which aren't.

Rocchio is a relevance feedback algorithm that updates queries to move closer to the relevant documents.

Pseudo relevance feedback is a method by which a system performs relevance feedback by assuming the top results returned by a system are relevant. Relevance feedback means that the user gives feedback on which documents are relevant and which aren't.

Rocchio is a pseudo relevance feedback algorithm that updates queries to move closer to the relevant documents.

Pseudo relevance feedback is a method by which a system performs relevance feedback by assuming the top results returned by a system are relevant. Relevance feedback means that the user gives feedback on which documents are relevant and which aren't.

Rocchio is a pseudo relevance feedback algorithm that updates queries to move closer to the relevant documents.

https://nlp.stanford.edu/IR-book/pdf/09expand.pdf

Yeah I wrote the student answer and I realize I misspoke, Rocchio is not the pseudo relevance algorithm but an algorithm to update queries to get more relevant results.
Adding on, I think you can use Rocchio in combination with relevance feedback or pseudo relevance feedback.

history.subject: Co-occurance matrix understanding
history.content:
From the  demo code in class, I saw the definition of the co-occurance_matrix, I was wondering is the element in the matrix the term frequency of each doc or binary representation?

# from sklearn.preprocessing import normalize
# doc_by_vocab2 = normalize(doc_by_vocab, axis=0)
# term_doc_matrix = doc_by_vocab.T
cooccurence_matrix = np.dot(term_doc_matrix.T, term_doc_matrix)

Thank you.

Each element at (i,j) of the co occurrence matrix represents the number of documents where term i and term j co occur. We do the matrix operation $$A^TA$$ instead of taking dot products of the columns corresponding to each term separately. (A is the term document matrix)
Each element at (i,j) of the co occurrence matrix represents the number of documents where term i and term j co occur.

@466 and @467 will give you more insights (on how PMI plays into it) as well. 

Also note that, the co-occurrence matrix is $$A^TA$$ if the term-document matrix A is a binary matrix with values of 0/1 if the term is in the document.

@466 and @467 will give you more insights (on how PMI plays into it) as well. 

Also note that, the co-occurrence matrix is $$<nobr>A^TA</nobr>$$ if the term-document matrix A is a binary matrix with values of 0/1 if the term is in the document.
@466 and @467 will give you more insights (on how PMI plays into it) as well.
@466 and @467 will give you more insights as well.

children.subject: Super helpful! Thanks
Does matrix A have to be binary? Is there a version of the co occurance matrix with a non binary A?

If the co-occurance matrix was nonbinary (say, number of occurences in each doc), we would get weighted values when calculating ATA.  This would give a lot of weight to documents that contain both term i and j, but many of term i or term j (or both).  In the case of the co-occurence matrix, this does not give us the most accurate information regarding co-occurence.  There may be an application of this nonbinary of this A, but in terms of using the co-occurence matrix to leverage PMI, the binary matrix is most truthful to co-occurence.
What about tf-idf weights? I think your same logic holds but thought I'd ask to see if anyone else has any input on this.

I think the point of using binary is to represent two words (i.e. word A , word B) occuring together in the same file. However, it will make less sense if we denote word A occurring in doc1 for 3 times, and word B occuring in doc1 for 2 times, and their occurance is 6 in this case. But all we need is to know word A and word B co-occured in doc, which could simply be represented if we were using binary.

history.subject: Generalized Jaccard
history.content: I'm conceptually confused on how Generalized Jaccard works based on the min/max of the frequency weights.

Generalized Jaccard softens the constraint of simple Jaccard that the count of word appearances can only be binary and takes into account that we want to reward overlapping occurrences of the same words. Since in non-binary counting, the overlap between two documents regarding a particular word type is exactly the minimum number of occurrences of the word type in one of the documents, the numerator is min(..).

For example, Document 1 = AAA BB, Document 2 = A BB and Document 3 = AAA B

We notice that 1 and  3 are probably most similar to each other since they have the same number of A occurrences and 3 is only 1 B short of 1 (while 2 is 2 A off 1), the Generalized Jaccard helps us materialize this Intuition by rewarding the greater overlap regarding a word type: so JG(1,3) = 3+1/3+2 = 4/5 and JG(1,2) = 1+2/3+2 = 3/5

history.subject: Why Cosine over Euclidean?
history.content:
May be outside the scope of this class but - from what I understand, both Euclidean and cosine preserve the same rankings, though cosine has closer distances. 

We can see this relationship here in this little tool. 
https://projector.tensorflow.org/

<md>You run into the issue of curse of dimensionality (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curse_of_dimensionality) with Euclidean, since the more dimensions and words there are the further everything is from each other. Cosine similarity helps avoid this by removing the length of the query/documents from consideration while also not punishing documents for being too long or rewarding documents for being extremely short (which can happen with euclidean).

history.subject: Jaccard vs Cosine Similarity
history.content: What are the tradeoffs of using either of these measures? When is it better to use one instead of the other?

I would look at our last assignment for a good numerical analysis. But it appears cosine has less tradeoffs between precision and recall.

Also this may help: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosine_similarity

"[Cosine similarity is] a judgment of orientation and not magnitude: two vectors with the same orientation have a cosine similarity of 1, two vectors oriented at 90° relative to each other have a similarity of 0, and two vectors diametrically opposed have a similarity of -1, independent of their magnitude"
I would look at our last assignment for a good numerical analysis. But it appears cosine has less tradeoffs between precision and recall

In addition to the student's answer, consider what each measure is looking at and how that may impact your results (for example the last assignment cosine similarity was looking at the words in the movies vs Jaccard looked at the genre of the movies).

history.subject: Midterm Quiz question
history.content:
For the midterm quiz, i remember there was a question about edit distance, we went through in class about how to change the code such that the edit distance for the first 3 letters are *3 times higher than the other changes. 

I am still confused about why do we only change for deletion to +3, but not for insertion, and keep it to +1?

Any insight would be helpful! Thank you!
With insertion you are not actually changing one of the first 3 letters

Also the questions are available in @377

Read carefully the question and the parentheses: we only care about the first three letters of the Source:  Source letters can only be deleted or substituted.  (Target letters are the ones that get inserted)
also the questions are available in @377

children.subject: That makes sense. Thank you
Does this mean that substitution for the first three letters would be +6? Since initially penalty is +2 and we triple it?

It would be more logical to assign a cost of 4 to the substitution cost for the first 3 letters. Since deletion cost is 3 and insertion cost is 1, and a substitution is a combination of deletion and insertion, the substitution should have an equivalent cost of their sum, which is 3 + 1 = 4. However, if substitution cost was 6, then the final answer would be the same since the algorithm defaults to a deletion and insertion when trying to perform a substitution, which still has cost 4.
great answer.

history.subject: "classic (ad hoc) information retrieval system"?
history.content: Can someone explain what is meant as a "classic (ad hoc) information retrieval system"?

[PROF DNM: picture removed, violates the Syllabus note about recording and distributing course materials.]

——————————

Sorry about that. 
Ad hoc means - when necessary or needed. 
So when necessary information retrieval system. 
It typically goes like this 
A user has an information need -> they write a query to represent that need -> and that query is used to get a result from the IR system. As for how to measure how good that result is, we use various similarity measures (as we did in class). 
We have also seen ways to evaluate these rankings such as looking into precision and recall and how to provide relevant feedback to a query such as with the rocchio method.

history.subject: Question about PMI Equations and Meaning
history.content:
I have written in my notes for PMI that $$P(a,b) = \frac{n_{ab}}{N}$$ and $$PMI = log\frac{P(a,b)}{P(a)P(b))}$$. Could someone explain what $$n_{ab}$$ and $$N$$ are and what these probabilities represent? I have written in my notes that $$a$$ and $$b$$ are words but in the textbook and another Piazza post (@466) I saw mention of assocation between words and a class? 

Thanks

Nab is the number of docs in which term a and term b co-occur.

N is the total number of docs

P(a,b) is the probability that among all docs, how many docs contain both term a and b.

P(a,b) could be a way to measure the co-occurrence of term a and b, but PMI is better because if two words occur by chance, then PMI=0, but P(a,b) cannot explain this.

Nab is the number of docs in which term a and term b co-occur.

N is the total number of docs

P(a,b) is the probability that among all docs, how many docs contain both term a and b.

To unpack a bit the student answer:  you can think what would be the probability of seeing a and b (i.e., P(a,b)) in the same document if there would be no connection between these words (i.e., the events of a occurs is independent of the event that b occurs).  It is the probability that word a occurs P(a) multiplied by the probability word b appears P(b), that is, P(a,b)=P(a)*P(b)  (you know this formula from your discrete math background).   If P(a, b) > P(a)P(b) then that simply means that a and b occur in the corpus more than one would expect by chance.  If P(a, b) < P(a)P(b)  then it means occur less than one would expect by chance.    I also offered an alternative explanation on how to get to PMI in class (via Bayes' theorem), but i don't think that is what you're asking.

Also, PMI can be found using matrix math, the term-doc-matrix, and coooccurance-matrix:

pa = np.sum(term_doc_matrix,0)
PMI_part = cooccurence_matrix / pa
PMI = PMI_part.T / pa

history.subject: Term document matrix

The term document matrix is formed by setting the documents as rows and the terms as columns. The entry (i, j) represents the frequency of term j in document i.

history.subject: Cumulative Gain and Discounted Cumulative Gain
history.content: What do cumulative gain and discounted cumulative gain represent/tell us about how good a system is? I'm a little confused about the information that the measures actually convey.

Cumulative gain and discounted cumulative gain are both measures of how "good" an information retrieval system is. Discounted cumulative gain takes into account the order in which documents are returned. Intuitively if two systems return 10 documents, 2 of which are relevant, but the first system returns the two relevant documents first and the other returns them last, the first system is better. If we looked at just the cumulative gain, both systems would appear to perform equally well, but discounted cumulative gain would tell us that the first system performed better.

===

Prof DNM:

Overall DCG aims to give a score to how well a system performs on a query.

The idea of "gain" is that each relevant document that your system returns should increase the score of the system.   In the DCG formula, the gain appears on the numerator.  While I gave you the most broadly used gain functions, in principle, you can redefine your "gain" function as appropriate.

The idea of "discount" is that the "gain" should be discounted if the respective document appears lower in the ranking.   In the DCG formula, the discount appears on the denominator.  

While I gave you the most broadly used discount functions,  in principle, you can redefine your "discount" function as appropriate.

Cumulative gain and discounted cumulative gain are both measures of how "good" an information retrieval system is.  Discounted cumulative gain takes into account the order in which documents are returned.  Intuitively if two systems return 10 documents, 2 of which are relevant, but the first system returns the two relevant documents first and the other returns them last, the first system is better. If we looked at just the cumulative gain, both systems would appear to perform equally well, but discounted cumulative gain would tell us that the first system performed better.
